Posts.Content: Im so thankful for this forum. I just had my RP on Aug 24 and just had the catheter removed on Aug 31. I felt so emasculated after looking at what happened to me. Good to know that Im not the only one and it will take some time to get back to normal Dx 6/2018, Age 48 PSA: 3/2017 - 7.5 5/2017 - 3.96 11/2017 - 4.04 5/2018 - 4.56 4KScore indicated high cancer risk Biopsy: 5/12 cores tested positive. 3 with Gleason 7 (3+4) and 2 with Gleason 6 CAT scan: negative Bone scan: negative RP: 8/24/18
Posts.Title: Penis question post op and post catheter removal

Posts.Content: I was recently diagnosed with prostate cancer and will be getting a robotic prostatectomy next month. I told them at work that I will be in the hospital and then home for 2 weeks. I have a job where I can even work from home once released from the hospital, and they are fine with that. However, I did not go into details of my diagnosis, since I legally do not have to. I did not disclose due to career concerns and dont want it to ever raise questions about my ability. How did you handle your employer regarding your diagnosis? Did you disclose everything or keep things private?
Posts.Title: Recently diagnosed - Do you tell boss/coworkers?

Posts.Content: I was recently diagnosed with prostate cancer and will be getting a robotic prostatectomy next month. I told them at work that I will be in the hospital and then home for 2 weeks. I have a job where I can even work from home once released from the hospital, and they are fine with that. However, I did not go into details of my diagnosis, since I legally do not have to. Did you disclose everything or keep things private?
Posts.Title: Recently diagnosed - Do you tell boss/coworkers?

Posts.Content: Just taking an informal poll to see how others handled the same situation. I know there is nothing wrong with keeping things confidential. The news came as a shock considering that I’m only 48 and never had any prior health problems in the past. It took time for me to process and think things through. My wife and I told our family first, but I didn’t even tell my closest guy friends until last week.

Posts.Title: Recently diagnosed - Do you tell boss/coworkers?

Posts.Content: The PSA test just happened to be part of the blood work by my regular doctor during my annual physical. When the PSA came in at 7.5, I was referred to a urologist for further testing. The doctor performing the procedure is the chief of robotic surgery at the hospital I will be going to.

Posts.Content: Hi, I had my RALP done 2 weeks ago. Continence is much better than expected. I think I only leaked 2-3 times in the past 10 days. Still waiting to go over the pathology report in another 3 weeks and do another PSA test. How do they determine if RT will be needed? If my PSA is 0 or undetectable, does that alone mean no RT? Just curious. Thanks. Mike
Posts.Signature: Dx 6/2018, Age 48 PSA: 3/2017 - 7.5 5/2017 - 3.96 11/2017 - 4.04 5/2018 - 4.56 4KScore indicated high cancer risk Biopsy: 5/12 cores tested positive. 3 with Gleason 7 (3+4) and 2 with Gleason 6 CAT scan: negative Bone scan: negative RP done on 8/24/2018 PSA 10/2018: 0.02
Posts.Title: RALP done 2 weeks ago - Next steps

Posts.Content: The 4K Score is not an alternative to a prostate biopsy. Think of it as a preliminary test to determine if you should have a biopsy. The 4K Score test does NOT determine if you have cancer. Only a biopsy can do that. The 4K score test is a blood test that determines if you are at a high risk of prostate cancer and is usually done on men with a PSA > 3.0. While a PSA of 3.0 is acceptable by itself, a 4K score test showing you at a high risk will result in your Urologist recommending you for a biopsy. If it comes out as low risk, then your Urologist may simply continue to monitor your PSA. When my PSA started climbing, I had the 4K score test. When the results showed me as high risk, then I had my biopsy 2 weeks later.
Posts.Signature: Dx 6/2018, Age 48 PSA: 3/2017 - 7.5 5/2017 - 3.96 11/2017 - 4.04 5/2018 - 4.56 4KScore indicated high cancer risk Biopsy: 5/12 cores tested positive. 3 with Gleason 7 (3+4) and 2 with Gleason 6 CAT scan: negative Bone scan: negative RP done on 8/24/2018 PSA 10/2018: 0.02
